meta.title: Foundations of Human-AI Interactions @ ICML 2026 (Proposal Submitted)

hero.titleHTML: Foundations of Human–AI Interactions:<br class="d-none d-md-block">Theory, Algorithms, Practice
hero.lead: AI is increasingly experienced as an interactive system—not a static predictor. This workshop proposal focuses on the science of interaction: human factors (reliance, trust calibration, cognitive effort, decision quality) and the algorithmic foundations needed to design interactive AI responsibly.

about.text: Modern AI systems are embedded in workflows where users ask follow-ups, negotiate meaning, revise goals, and calibrate trust over time. Yet most ML objectives and benchmarks remain static. We aim to build a common foundation that connects (i) human-centered measurement, (ii) algorithm design for interaction, and (iii) theory that clarifies what can be guaranteed about long-horizon human–AI outcomes.

cards.title: Human factors as objectives
cards.body: Study and optimize measurable outcomes: trust calibration, reliance, cognitive effort, error recovery, and decision quality.

cards.title: Bridging HCI ↔ ML foundations
cards.body: Translate user studies into objectives, training signals, and evaluation protocols that can be iterated and audited.

cards.title: Evaluation beyond static accuracy
cards.body: Move toward multi-turn and longitudinal evaluation where failures emerge through interaction dynamics.
